comment.author: 76908540@N04
comment._content: Nice shot but the photograph has been reversed: the mammisi is on the right side of the court ! True, a slide can be watched from both sides, but buldings don't move so easily from west to east...

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content:
Thanks, Luke. We'll confirm with our curatorial staff and flip if they confirm.
Good catch!
Deb Wythe
Digital Lab

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content:
Hi Luke, Our curator responded: I'm not absolutely sure, but I think this image is correct. The photographer is standing inside the first court looking out. The commenter is thinking of the multiple photos toward the entrance from the outside with a colonnade that runs into the pylon. But I have not been there in years.
Best,
Deb Wythe

comment.author: 76908540@N04
comment._content: Hi Deb, Thanks for investigating ! Your curator is (partly) right : the photographer was inside the first court looking out, that is southwards... But the commenter is thinking of the temple itself, not of other photos ;-) When the 19th century photographer was in the first court, the mammisi was on his right side (west side of the court), as can be checked on maps (for example upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/44/GD-EG-Philaé... , ndastarac.free.fr/philae/images/planphil.jpg ) or more recent photographs (www.insecula.com/salle/photo_ME0000077073.html , www.insecula.com/salle/photo_ME0000077071.html , www.philae.nu/akhet/Philaemammissi.html (2nd picture), etc.). Compare to the same mammisi, but looking northwards, that is towards the 2nd pylon (www.phouka.com/tr/egypt/photos/aswan/philae/mammisi-01.html , www.philae.nu/akhet/Philaemammissi.html (1st picture) , www.insecula.com/salle/photo_ME0000077072.html , www.jomaya.com/destinations/egypte/jour-5-philae/ , etc.). Any more doubts ? Hope you'll be able to visit Philae again soon ! Best, Luke

Deb Wythe
